description:
It's weird that Yelp calls this "Chinatown" because this was clearly in North Beach. 

Just passing by, we were attracted to this place by the welcoming vibe and live jazz. The door man (young African American man) was very nice for a door man (more like what you'd expect from a restaurant host), and even though he carded two people in our 40s, you can't fault a guy for doing his job! SF's alcohol enforcement unit ain't getting nothing past this guy, haha. He even thanked us for coming in when we left, which again, is more friendly than door people I'm used to on the East coast. Both he and the bartender were friendlier than the employees in Vesuvio Cafe, which is why we quickly left that place and were looking for somewhere else to hang.

The bartender (young white male, brown hair) was totally friendly and helpful with our drink selections. 

The jazz quartet all had great chops. The drummer had to be in his 70s or 80s, but he was a real pro and delight to watch, and the guitarist later told us he was a legend on the local jazz scene.  [Side rant: I hope the young, techy residents of SF appreciate what they have in their jazz musicians - it's a dying art, notoriously underpaid, and the men and women keeping it going are both more cool and talented than you'll ever be. Don't buy the latest Google glass or whatever; support your local musicians, ya dopes.]

The decor was outstanding. I want that wallpaper.
author: Haltone H.

description:
Dropped a couple of stars for poor, surly service the second time around.
After being encouraged to make a reservation the last time I was there (when I told them we'd be back with a group of six people next time)-- we walked into a mostly empty bar.  (There were only two people sitting at the bar and two at a table when we walked in.)
Our reservation was for 5 pm.  Dinner was at 6pm around the corner.
Confused, I walked up to the bar thinking maybe they weren't open yet. (They opened at 3pm)
I told the barkeep we had a reservation and asked where we should sit.
I thought maybe they had a designated area for larger groups.
He didn't even look up and gestured with his hand to sit anywhere you wanted.
We sat at a table that could accommodate six people and waited for a server.  I was told the last time that there was a server for people at tables.
After 10 minutes, I went back to the bar and ordered drinks from the same barkeep.  He told me that the server starts at 5pm.  A server 
never showed up and we were there until 6pm.  He could have cared less.  
Heavy drapes were partially closed at the windows to keep the bright sunlight from coming in where the tables are located.
The only other guy working there (barback?) decided to fling them open which caused us and other people to move to different tables because it was so uncomfortably bright and warm.  We asked him to partially close them a bit to get the sun out of our eyes and he said, "No" and walked away.
Again, this one too could have cared less.  
If you live in SF, you have likely experienced this attitude that seems to permeate the service industry here. There is often an attitude where the customer comes second.  Time to own it and for people to start asking for better service.
author: Thomas D.

description:
It's very crowded at this bar, and they don't sell coffee or energy drinks. They also did not have a big selection of alcohol, however when I asked him for something sweet he made some amaretto sours and they were delicious! 


Environment is very hippie laid back, not huge diverse crowd here. 

-staff is friendly and knowledgeable

-very small bar
author: Lupe H.

description:
Very cool trendy bar. There are many in the financial district but this place stood out to me. The atmosphere is great with some classic tunes in the background. The barkeep know their stuff as it's reflected in their creative drinks. Very clean and nice inside. 

Great drink menu with a variety of cocktails or just tell them what you're in the mood for and they'll come up with an amazing concoction for you. No food at all here which kinda sucks perhaps just a few apps would help. I found myself getting hungry so I had to leave to get pizza. Lol
author: Cary R.

description:
We stumped on this place by walking around after having dinner and dropping in at a taproom for a beer.  The place was lively and the bartenders were friendly.  They did have security checking ID and the crowd was mixed, mostly early twenties folks.  

The menu is quirky and it's printed like a comic book.  The bartenders, in addition to Bering friendly are true mixologist.  Many of the cocktails have egg whites in them, but you can also tell them what you're feeling and they will mix something up for you.  The music is great as well and the place is more of a social environment.  No food, just drinks!  If you're around stop in for a cocktail.
author: Jay O.

description: Fun, speakeasy bar with great decor and ambiance. Prices are good and seating is plenty. Fun place for a date or wine night with your girlfriends. Ive also been there when they have live music, which is def a plus!
author: Lillian W.

description: Decent cocktail bar with ample seating around. Great for a larger group or a small group if you want to grab a seat at the bar. The downstairs area is quite cool if you prefer something quieter. The cocktails themselves are quite good and the bartenders really know what they are doing. Come check it out!
author: Taylor Z.

description:
As bars go, this one has a lot going for it.  The bartenders look very cutting edge--they all have the requisite shaved head, full beard, and extensive tats.  They also know their craft.  I've been to plenty of big-city speakeasies and these guys compare pretty favorably in terms of pure mixology.  Their custom cocktails are imaginative and the ones we had were all delicious, though they ran the gamut from light to 'spiritous' and  the server was very precise in describing them to us in detail.  

The only place they messed up is that we had a bigger party so we called for a reservation.  When we got there, the only person visible in the bar was the bartender, who didn't know about the reservation, and every table had a sign that said "reserved" on it, so we didn't know where to sit.  The bartender didn't know either, so we commandeered a few tables and pulled them together.  When the server showed up she said it wasn't where they wanted to put us but they weren't going to move us either.  

Not a big deal, nobody died or went to prison, but not quite the 5-star performance.  I'd definitely recommend it though.  A nice place with a good vibe and great drinks.
author: George R.

description:
Really enjoyed! It's in the heart of the city so to speak with lots of diversity all around. I found parking close i posted a picture below, pretty reasonable.
The drinks were tasty with a bit of a punch! (And I don't mean fruit punch)
We were there on a Saturday night had a couple tables reserved for my sons birthday party.  There was also another celebration going on at the same time.
They handle the crowds great, service was excellent and as I said the drinks were really good.  
So from one fellow Yellper to another Pop in to the Devils Acre... Cheers!
author: Anita V.

description: Excellent cocktails and a dark cozy ambiance. I can't wait to come back and order some of the other drinks off the menu.
author: Alana G.

description: We came here for a nightcap on my birthday and ended up getting a couple more than that... the drinks are just too good. Ordered one thing off the menu and experimented with letting the bartender do his thing. Everything was perfect, the vibe, the clientele, the service, the live music and of course the drinks. It's got that speakeasy atmosphere without being a hidden secret, but really, how many of those does one city need anyway?
author: New2Northbeach N.

description:
Charming saloon vibe that really captures the past 
Drinks are good, true to flavors 
Seating is good and spread across the space 

Overall Thoughts

A great date spot in the North Beach area
author: Eddie W.

description:
Great drinks
Entertaining Barkeeper, smart ass
We had the DuPont- sounds gross, but outstanding
author: John G.

description:
My love for bars in San Francisco always grows exponentially due to places like these. Dimly lit, decently sized, rustic looking bar in the north beach area just besides th popular italian place E tutto qua. The area itself picks up at night and that's the first reason I would choose a place like this on a Friday night. 

I just feel that bars that are a little more spaced out and less cozy dont give me s great feel, but this one did the job. The ambience is amazing but the drinks are pricey and less in quantity, they are strong though. We were there from 11 until 1 am but it never got that crowded. It is a little slow as compared to other bars in the north beach area. If you want to sit and chat at a bar, yes this is the place.
author: Foram C.

description:
Since my last visit, a few things have changed.

The menu is now much more brief - only one page.  That said, if nothing is standing out to you, you can ask for many other cocktails.  The bartenders have extensive knowledge and will help you find something that works for you!

There are bar stools now as well. :)
author: Lisa P.

description:
When it comes to cocktails, this place is about as good as its gonna get in San Francisco.  Super innovative cocktails, these guys are creating their own vermouth blends, making their own bitters using pisco instead of neutral spirits, and absolutely crushing it in terms of ambiance with the live jazz.

If you like Chartreuse, the Call a Treuse is the way to go, and they have some stuff off menu as well to keep you interested.

This is now the go-to cocktail bar in North Beach as far as I'm concerned.
author: Chad T.

description:
God this place is amazing. Was looking for a nice "hip" bar to visit while in town and this was recommended to me. Boy am I glad I came, their drinks are amazing! Amongst the most memorable drinks (for what I can remember at least....) were the Sherry Cobbler, Three Sworn Enemies, and the Mojitos.

Let me tell you a little something about my relationship with cocktails: the more extra it is THE BETTER. I have never had a cocktail with edible gold dust in it and the Three Sworn Enemies was perhaps the most exciting drink i've ever had in my life. While strong, I loved watching this drink glisten in the dimly lit bar. I couldn't have been happier with it!

Definitely somewhere i'd recommend for other people in SF. It's the kind of place where you'd take people for a good drink and nice conversation. Come for their happy hour (ends at 7PM) where drinks are actually super cheap!

Will definitely be back very, very soon!!
author: Michael C.

description: Great drinks and servers are very nice.  Noise level makes it difficult to carry on a conversation.
author: Chris O.

description:
I've been to a couple of The Devil's Acre's sister bars and I LOVE each of them with their cute themes, but an apothecary may be a hard one to replicate. Even so, I think they did pretty well. Their "single-hole waterfall" faucet in the bathroom was a nice touch. I would've LOVED to see their Remedie Room, but it seems it's reserved for private events only.

As always, their drinks were great! The Bourbon Crusta, Pisco Punch, and the Golden Era were delicious - Boyfriend says Golden Era tasted like apple pie. The bartender put edible gold dust in the Three Sworn Enemies!!!! It was SUPER pretty, but the orange bitters were a little much. I would've tried the Pineapple Julep too, but 3 drinks would've had me throwing up on the sidewalk...
author: Athena C.

description: Great ambiance, delicious drinks, fun atmosphere! One of the bartenders had somewhat of a weird attitude with us but we didn't let it dampen our spirits. I like the feel of this establishment and the classic cocktails they offer. We were here early in the evening on New Years Eve and the place became packed shortly after we arrived. Although I don't usually like any vermouth in my vodka martini, the martini we ordered had their homemade vermouth in it and it was to die for. Really impressed with the drink selection and the attention to detail in each hand crafted drink. Great little spot.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I don't often come across original cocktails that shock and awe, but man do I LOVE ME SOME CHARTREUSE! It was the "Call a Treuse": Green Chartreuse, Yellow Chartreuse, Dry Vermouth, lemon, Vanilla Syrup, Egg Whites, Gold Rush Bitters, Thyme. 

I absolutely loved the atmosphere, and it wasn't hard to get a small candlit table to catch up with a friend while we got some pre-dinner drinks. The music, the crowd, the service, the menu- top notch.
author: Lauren M.

description: This place is a must-do! Jack is hands down the best bartender I have encountered in a long time. He welcomed us immediately, and he was patient with all of our questions. We stumbled upon this gem after dinner for a cocktail, and we ended up bellying up for what ended up to be a great education in craft cocktails. Thanks, "Jamal." We will be back!
author: Joanne R.

description: This is a fun spot if you enjoy mixology. If you want a quick drink this is not the spot for you. The mixologists make delicious drinks. And I am pleased everything I stop by. Even liquids I normally don't enjoy, I enjoy here bc they know how to make great cocktails.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Phillip L. and I had wanted to dine at Hog Island Oyster Co., but when we got to the Ferry Building, they had a sign saying they were closed for the rest of the day because of plumbing issues. Just our luck!  Thankfully the weather wasn't too cold (for San Francisco), so we ended up just walking towards the North Beach neighborhood since we were having dinner with Starr. C and her boyfriend later that night. 

Instead of looking on Yelp like I usually do, we ended up picking a bar that we thought looked cool and just went in. The Devil's Acre was dark and romantic, but they had a great happy hour, which they called the Devil's Hour, hah.

Devil's Hour (Monday-Saturday until 7pm, and all night Sunday) included:
- $5 taps
- $8 olympia + bourbon or tecate + tequila
- $8 old fashion
- $8 chardonnay or cabernet

Of course, my boyfriend went classy with a cocktail and the old fashion, while I was pounding tequila shots and beers. I mean, if there's a shot and beer deal, I always have to get it. ;) Cheers!
author: Christine S.

description: The establishment is unparalleled, being from out of town and choosing this bar I feel was the best decision for an edgy, unique slice of SF. I wasn't afraid to ask the waitress to surprise me for my cocktail because I just couldn't decide. The whole menu looked amazing and I was not disappointed!
author: Andrea M.

description: The drinks here are good. The music here is too loud (just saying), and the interior is pretty well designed. The bartenders know how to make a good cocktail and they are worth the price in my book. Overall a decent place to pop in for a drink. I am not a tween or a tech bro so thought the crowd tended to flow in that direction as the evening wore on, but otherwise for my set of friends it is a good meeting up and "first or second" drink place for sure.
author: Marc R.

description: I walked in with my fiancé and waited for 15 minutes while one bartender served an entire bar full of people. I know it was a Sunday eve and they're probably expecting a small crowd, but this place was severely understaffed. I give them three stars for a great playlist and solid ambiance that made our wait more bearable before we had to leave after seeing no progression in the line at the bar.
author: Colton S.

description: The best part of this bar is Velma... Could benefit from another bar tender and a more friendly staff.
author: Matthew K. Harris H.

description:
Came in for a quick pre-dinner drink and really enjoyed the gin thing I had. I forget what it was called, but of the two gin options, it fit the blustery fall weather better.

Weird thought: the bar has too many seats and there's not enough space between them, making getting in and out of your seat difficult unless you were to maybe hop over it. Which,is probably inappropriate.
author: Misha T.

description: These beverages are beautifully crafted. We even challenged the bartenders Jack and Chad to make us a vodka drink with egg whites. I don't know what he made us but it was delicious. Creative and talented bartenders plus a cool vibe. If I lived in SF, I would likely be a regular.
author: Monica D.

description:
This place is busy even on Tuesday night. It is very loud, we almost can not hear the music. All the crowd is mostly by the bar area, so it is really hard to get a drink as the line is long and it is unclear where it is starts.  
       They dont have cocktail waitresses so getting a drink is a bit$h
author: Mary T.

description:
I've been here several times and each time I was intrigued by the vibe of the space & decor. Speakeasy bar with a twist I guess you can say...found out there is a downstairs portion to the bar that you can ask to be seated at but there was plenty of seats at the top floor. 
Great for a group of people or just two...there's a menu of mixed drinks or beers. I just stick to what I know & order an old fashioned.
author: Nicole A.

description: Hella slow to make and pot drinks.  Bartender seemed confused and offended when I told him to cancel my drink after ten minutes of just standing there with a non busy bar.
author: victor b.

description: Nice intimate bar with a decent selection by the glass.. a bit loud music but cozy and well design place to chill and drink.. service is friendly and unpretentious..
author: Ray K.

description:
Pluses: the interior is cool vintage. The mixologists are very serious. Minuses: out of four cocktails, only one was a semi-hit. Even their version of a Manhattan seemed off. We look for balance and complexity. A cocktail always loses if it's overly sweet or doesn't play with its ingredients well. A very noisy interior. And like so many of these places, no munchies to even out the ingestion of the spirits. 

On the face, the drinks look very creative, but they just didn't do anything for us. Will try again when their menu changes.
author: Gregory Z.

description:
Great for a date night or a large birthday! 

Devil's Acre has plenty of space to stand, but there are also a lot of individual tables if you just want to talk in a smaller group. I love that they open all the windows when it's warm out, so get a table there if you're there around happy hour!

While I have only tried two of their cocktails and remember the names of zero, they were both good. Not the fastest service because some of them are a bit fancyyyy but it's worth the wait.

There was on we ordered that looked like kid's makeup / an arts and crafts project, which was pretty cool. It was clear but with yellow / gold soooo look for it on the menu!
author: Jennifer L.

description: My husband and I really loved this place last time we were here. Coming now, staff were rude to us and allowed us to wait outside for 20 plus minutes until we called and stated we were waiting outside for you to open. Staff rudely stated we don't open until 9 and I'm putting a sign up now. While the website states 3pm. Didn't apologize or care. Won't be going back
author: Janel S.

description: Chad is an amazing alchemist... told him what I like and he made the most amazing drink! Roaring 20's vibe... a little load... but a great place to stop and have a drink or two!!
author: Tarah D.

description:
If I were to give Devil's Acre a rating based on my first time experience here, I'd give it negative stars off the bat.

Came in with +1 and we sat at the bar near the wall. The bartenders on duty were rude and totally brushed us off. It was a Tuesday night mind you! The bar was empty and there were a few straggler patrons here and there so there was no excuse for the lack of attentiveness. One of the bartenders had ear gauges and I've seen him manning the bar the second time around too but luckily for him I had a different bartender tend to my needs, otherwise I would have given him a shot at redemption.

The second time around I came with a girlfriend and we received much better service. We sat at the bar and the bartenders serving us were very attentive. There was one asian guy and a gal with curly hair. I told her to whip me up a drink with pisco and she asked what flavor profiles I liked so she could create her unique concoction. It was delicious! 

I had about 4 cocktails here: all very strong! Especially the Three Sworn Enemies. Truthfully I had ordered it because it had glitter and my favorite color is glitter but all in all it was a strong drink that'll make the hairs off your feet curl up.

Not quite 5 stars (yet) but I'll be back to taste other vices they serve or anything infused with glitta.
author: Connie M.

description: Service coming into the place was just OK. But once we finally got a seat at the bar those guys took great care of us.
author: Austin R.

description: Stopped into this gem and absolutely fell in love with the Chartruese drink (I think it was called let's call a truese, or something like that). I had never had it before and I've gone to two other places since asking for Chartruese drinks and they didn't have anything on the Devil's Acre. The bartender was AWESOME, super funny and nice, our group had a blast, will absolutely be back next time we're in the bay area.
author: Heidi C.

description: A great little cocktail bar in SF! My boyfriend and I came here before dinner reservations one Saturday night, and the cocktails were great. We grabbed a table in the back and both ordered the Golden Era. I stumbled upon this place on yelp because it was right around the corner from where we were getting dinner, and I'm glad we stopped in!
author: Morgan S.

description:
My coworkers and I stopped in on our way to a restaurant. They were playing jazz music, So I think that's what attracted us. I ordered some but my co-workers ordered 2 different drinks with pineapple and they loved them! 

I personally don't like pineapple, So I which they had more of a cocktail selection, so I don't continue to get the same boring drinks. 

It also smelled like, What i thought was bleach or chlorine (at least at the bar), so I think that's what made it less welcoming for me. 
It would definitely be a strong 3 1/2
author: J. A.

description:
I almost never feel compelled to write a review, so it must be good, right? My boyfriend and I were checking out some cocktail bars in San Fran recently and this one really stuck out due to overall experience. The drinks kick ass, the decor kicks ass, the bartender/GM kicks ass.

Ask for Jack (I think that was his name); he's the best.

We'll be going back for sure to try their new drink menu when we're back in town!
author: Sebrina T.

description: This place is so cool! A great place to come with a large group of friends or a date to relax and get some pre-dinner drinks. And then come back and get after-dinner drinks. And then for a pre-bedtime drink.
author: Divleen B.

description: Meh.  We had the Three sworn enemies & pisco punch....Both disappointing- more of a premixed drink than originals. The staff didn't seem very enthusiastic or interested to be there, and I'm not sure what vibe they're going for in the place.
author: Rob M.

description: This place has good drinks. Nothing over the top special. Their service is like too cool for you which is dumb. I get it, you work at a cool place but like your attitude makes you uncool and gives the place a weird vibe.
author: Jazlyn H.

description: Fantastic drinks!!! It's a great chill place to hang out with friends. Don't forget to make reservations to get a seat. And also come during happy hour 5-7pm. Service is kind of meh though, they don't really come by at all for refills...
author: Janet H.

description: It was a YELP review that guided us to this touch of history in a glass.  The bartender is amazing - spend some time asking about the drinks available and their history.  You will not be disappointed.  The location is great, the interior takes you back in time and you just feel like you have found one of those special places.
author: Rod F.

description: Loved this place! Excellent cocktails. We sat and chatted with the bartenders before the rush hit and were able to try a few different drinks based on what my husband and I each like. Great ambiance and excellent service by the whole team. Highly recommend!
author: Katie H.

description:
If you like unique, edgy places... check this place out. I had the Lauchlan's antiscorbutic (a gimlet) and I think I'd sell my soul to the devil for another (kidding).  

The atmosphere and genre is fun, the menu names are clever, and the staff is friendly.  Oh and the happy hour is quite generous.
author: Bahman M.

description:
I like how the cocktails here are not super strong like the other cocktail bars in the area. There are strong drinks but this is mostly well-crafted sweet and flavorful cocktails. Almost half the menu is dedicated to twists on nonalcoholic drinks and sodas. Good for very adult drinkers in your party.

Due to its spaciousness it never feels crowded packed, even on a busy night. Lots of tables for the space so you should be ok as a walk-in. And, turnover is relatively quick as it is more of a stopover before or after dinner. Make a reservation if you want peace of mind or are a large group.

I don't drink that often. Correction, I don't drink that often in North Beach, but this is my favorite cocktail bar there.
author: Peter L.

description:
Was looking for a nice place to chill/hangout after a birthday dinner and stumbled upon this place after some yelping. The space was very clean and elegant with candles lit at every table. While it isn't the biggest bar, there were more than enough empty tables on a Saturday night to seat a large group of 10 together. 

The drinks were pretty good - I tried the Pineapple Julep and a sip of my friend's ginger beer. One of my friends got the Prospector, which had gold sparkles in it. The overall ambiance was nice and comfortable. Great place to catch up with a group of friends.
author: Kris C.

description:
Located in the hustle and bustle area of Columbus and Broadway, Devil's Acre has been blessed to be setup in a surprisingly large space. They take reservations and a table for you and your group shouldn't be too challenging to secure even without one on most evenings. Although there is plenty of shoulder room between tables, you're going to have to fight to be heard over other potentially louder tables.

As for their drink menu it looks and tastes splendid(based on two visits thus far). If you're a fan of bourbon, I recommend you try Three Sworn Enemies(bourbon, vanilla syrup, angostura & orange bitters, gold dust). 

Prices are quite reasonable, and between the large space and quality of libations, I can comfortably recommend this joint if you're in the North Beach area looking to wet your whistle.
author: Dennis W.

description: Came here Friday night with a friend for a drink. We sat at the bar, bartender wasn't the friendliest, but that's okay because we ordered drinks and they came out really pretty and also tasty. The ambiance was really nice. Low lighting, candles, bookcase, lanterns, lots of space. Cocktails are presented very well. Not super loud, you can talk and hear each other. I would return.
author: Marie D.

description:
You're late for work cause you missed your train ... For the 3rd time this week and it's only Wednesday. 

You trip on that last flight of stairs, spilling your $10 Blue Jamaican Philz coffee on your favorite shirt. 

Your mom calls you and leaves you a voicemail saying: "surprise! I'm in town and I'm at your apartment getting to know your new gf!" 

* Is this day over yet? * 

Everyone has bad days but the Devil has obviously picked you to be his guinea pig today. No worries, everything is cured with cocktails at the Devil's Acre.

The space is impressive and is layered with that old Barbary coast feeling: from the apothecary look of the menus, the massive wooden bar shelf, vintage decor and private space for parties at basement level. I dig it.

From the extensive amount of choices (you can even order sodas and phosphates like the good ol' days!) more than a few stand out. The Devil's Manhattan made with rye, sweet vermouth, bitters and a splash of champagne is supreme. It's everything you'd expect in a classic cocktail like this: it takes the flavor of whiskey and lets it shine, with an extra fun element of bubbly. You'll also love the pearl topped stirrer that is served with your Luxardo cherries.

The Bijou is what they call on the menu -- a period specific cocktail from the 1900. It has gin, sweet vermouth, green & yellow chartreuse and orange bitters. Its crisp, herbaceous qualities make for a fine drink on a cold winter night.

For Barbary Coast history buffs and cocktail fans, The Lauchlan's Antiscorbutic is a stiff cocktail that's sure to cure what ails you. In 1867, Lauchlan Rose patented a method where in he discovered that sulfur salts acted as a preservative agent for perishable juices. Rose's Lime juice cordial was born and you get plenty of lime flavor in this drink, along with vitamin C to cure scurvy. I mean, nowadays, if you had scurvy you would go to the hospital, but probably helps to pre-game with this cocktail before hand ;-) I'd probably choose the Paramour over anything else at this bar since it has Campari and the pretty pink color makes me happy every time I order it here. 

The Devil's Acre is suitable for date nights, small group gatherings or even post dinner meet-ups in North Beach when you don't want to burn money and go to the nearby Strip Clubs. Plus, in this town where people with disposable income have a Devil may care attitude in spending cashola, I appreciate the fact that the cocktails are still an affordable $10 each. To that I say, hallelujah!
author: Janice C.

description:
I used to love The Devil's Acre, but ever since they greatly reduced their cocktail menu, I just haven't been as much of a fan. Their menu now consists of 8ish drinks compared to the old menu that literally had pages of tasty drinks to try for each spirit, leaving you ready to come back and conquer more. I would keep coming if at least the new menu featured stars from the old menu, but I don't think it does. Most of our group found their drink to be bitter, which is bizarre given how much I used to enjoy their cocktails. Apparently you can still find the full menu downstairs, but it is usually closed.

Ambiance is still fantastic, but the new menu drops my review to just A-OK.
author: Sabina S.

description: Awesome Live 3piece jazz band. Great quipy but talented bartender Jack. Best whisky sour in SF. Highly recommend.
author: Matt R.

description:
1 star because of the terrible security!

My friends and I came here last night, a Friday night, and security wouldn't let one of my friends in because he was smoking his vape pen outside too close to the doors. I mean come on, he was outside he was not breaking the law.

A few of us ended up going in. The bar was pretty much empty. There's a single person bathroom upstairs and me and two girlfriends went in together. Girls go to the bathroom together all the time, it's harmless. Well, while my friend was on the toilet, security comes banging on the door screaming for us to open the door. He was yelling pretty aggressively, we thought something bad must've been going on. He forced us to open the door while my friend was exposed and mid pee, and made two of us leave the bathroom because it was 'a single use bathroom.' Not okay!! 

Unbelievable. Drinks were pretty good and the bartenders were great, but definitely not worth the bullshit security. Never going back again!
author: Chloe R.

description:
This is a cute little bar with craft drinks and an old time, speakeasy feel to it.

I know it's weird, but we were most impressed with the menu itself. So much thought and creativity was put into it. They listed the original creator and year a drink was created, and many popular choices similar to old fashioned drinks or gin, juniper and fruits were created in the 1800's. I noticed some of the drinks had over 10 ingredients! 

I'm kind of a whiskey on the rocks type of girl, but man. Whether you like strong or girly cocktails, just get any cocktail. It's a waste to get whiskey on the rocks here.

Service, however, falls a bit short (hence my giving 4 stars instead of 5). Our cute waitress with short black hair, bangs and black glasses (who seemed super not enthused to be there) seemed to really dislike patrons asking for drink suggestions and possibly has never smiled in her entire life.

My fiance figured this bar would be like the other craft cocktail/speakeasy type bars where bartenders are eager to surprise us with a nice, strong drink based off the tasting notes we like. I guess that was our mistake. I don't think this is that type of bar lol. 

He asked that the mixologist make whatever they thought would fit him best - something strong and bourbon/whiskey based, kind of like an old fashioned but with their own twist. They gave him a watered down old fashioned...

Lucky for me, I ordered Three Sworn Enemies based off other Yelp reviews. It had Evan Williams bottled in-bond bourbon, grand poppy, vanilla syrup, angostura and orange bitters, along with a few pinches and spritzes of other things. Last but not least, there was GOLD DUST! I sparkly and high just looking at it. Not a single ingredient was overpowering. They all complemented the other flavors in the drink, including my bourbon.

In a bar that's so passionate about their craft drinks, I feel that all staff members should be friendly, welcoming and helpful in choosing one of their many unique drinks. The vast majority of all craft cocktail bars we've visited have very upbeat, knowledgeable and helpful staff. 

Rating breakdown:

Drinks - 4.5/5  
Service - 3.5/5
Ambience - 4/5 (it can get really crowded and loud, but still pretty cute place)
author: Ivy C.

description:
Not gonna lie, what caught my interest in The Devil's Acre was that sparkly gold drink! After seeing pictures I knew I wanted it! We came on a Thursday evening around 8pm and there was plenty of seating and room both upstairs and downstairs. 

The sparkly gold drink is the Three Sworn Enemies. Since I'm not really a fan of bourbon, I ordered Call a Treuse. The Three Sworn Enemies is STRONG. It tasted like straight alcohol, I could barely handle a sip. BUT IT'S SO PRETTY!!! Luckily the bf was able to drink it (always taking one for the team =P) but he wasn't a fan of the bourbon that they used. I absolutely loved the Call a Treuse. It was light and tasty. Would recommend this drink!

The service was incredibly slow, even though there weren't many people at the bar at all. I could only imagine how long it would take to get a drink on a weekend!
author: Noelle H.

description: Went to a birthday here and it was great! I didn't plan the logistics but it seemed like they let us reserve a long table to fit a large group. The vibe was great (trendy and vibrant but quiet enough to catch up) and the drink I ordered was delicious. Options are limited for folks who don't drink bourbon or gin though.
author: Ana M.

description: The drinks were excellent but the service was better... didn't stand at the bar to order but our waitress (we didn't get her name) was thee BEST! Get the "Call a Treuse" or "Liquid Sunshine" and you'll be well set for the evening. The crowd was a little loud and trendy but maybe I'm just old. This place is definitely worth your patronage
author: Serge C.

description:
This is a fun place. We stopped by this place on new year's Eve for shots and it was good. They have an underground seating place as well which is private and great for dinner with friends. 

We did not sit there cause the music wasn't playing downstairs and we were in the mood to party. Fun place to hang out though.
author: Ramyata M.

description:
I met up with a few friends at The Devil's Arce before having dinner nearby.  It's a very nice bar!  Very spacious and multilevel.  It was around 8pm on a Saturday night and it wasn't too crowded with plenty of open tables on the main floor and at the bar in the basement.  Though I could only imagine the place getting much busier later in the night.

I ordered the Devil's Manhattan which was one of their signature drinks made with rye, sweet vermouth, Boker's and orange bitters.  It was a very delightful and refreshing libation.  I would've stuck around to try more cocktails, but we have to leave for dinner.

I definitely plan on going back to The Devil's Arce.  It's a great place to meet up with a group of friends and although I just had one cocktail, their drinks menu seems to be very solid.
author: Rodney H.

description:
This is it !!! One of the best spots I've been at since I've been here,  very cool ambiance and it resembles somewhat of a hipster speakeasy.

I ordered a boulevardier and my fiance ordered a sherry cobbler, the execution and craftmanship on the drinks were great, have I had a better boulevardier before?  Mmmm yes however this will definitely do. 

It's also got a sitting area that you can enjoy your drinks,  the liquors they use are higher grade which that's what you'd expect since you're not getting a typical well drink.

This place is definitely a 10 out of 10 
Great drinks
Great prices 
And more than anything they make a proper craft drink .
I will be back :)
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Used to love this spot! Really well decorated space with live bands sometimes, an intimate downstairs area, and an extensive cocktail list including drinks you wouldn't see elsewhere. I went back yesterday for the first time in over a year. The downstairs is closed and now they only have about 8 cocktails. The two gin ones we tried were awful- one was inedibly sour and the other tasted like flat soda water with a dash of flavor. We ended up leaving more than half of each on the table. Seemed like we weren't the only ones that felt that way- the place was very dead for a Friday and used to always be packed. Such a shame- used to be a great NB place for after dinner drinks.
author: Vinitha R.

description:
{Really more like 3.5 stars} 

Came here early on a Saturday. I was really excited to try this bar so let me explain the 3 stars. I probably would have given it at least four if the service was better. 

When we walked in it looked like there was only one bartender working, though the bar had a decent amount of people at it. We chose a table and studied the menu for a bit. We figured there was no table service but the bartender came over to us and immediately said "I need to see your ID's". No hello first or anything. So right there the service was pretty annoying. We were told we'd have to go to the bar to ordered (which we figured) so after deciding my friend and I went up to the bar to order. At this point the bartender was very friendly and let me even try the sherry before ordering the Sherry Cobbler. The drink was SO good. The amount of effort that went into making it was great. It was beautiful and delicious. My friends gin drink was also good and my husbands Three Sworn Enemies was not only beautiful it smelled and tasted amazing. 

After we finished those drinks my husband went back up to the bar to see if they would make him a Penicillin to which the bartender stated "NO". He felt like she was pretty rude and thought the customer service was terrible. He came back with 2 beers and was pretty disappointed. Also, by this time the bar was getting more and more crowded and still they only had one bartender. We didn't see another bartender come until almost 5:00. So, that woman was behind the bar for two hours serving everyone herself. I think she was overwhelmed and understaffed which is too bad because while the drinks were amazing and wonderfully crafted the service was lacking. When you're paying $10+ for a drink you hope the person making it is friendly. 

The service didn't completely ruin the experience by any means though and I would definitely come back in the future. Their menu was large and really fun. Lots more drinks I'd like to try. Also there bathroom was really cool and clean which I appreciate!
author: Kelli H.

description:
We had attempted to get pre-dinner drinks at Comstock Saloon but didn't care for the way we were treated over there, so we opted to come over here instead thanks to the Yelp reviews. Like Comstock Saloon (apparently) it was not super clear to us that we were supposed to be seated by someone--and the server was absent from the hostess stand for about five minutes. But when we were sort of edging into the seating area, the guy at the door got our attention and let us know we should wait for a seat--kindly.

The hostess was super friendly when she came over--it looked like she was handling the entire floor on her own so the delay was totally understandable. And the service was also really quick once we'd been seated. My husband ordered a beer with a name he couldn't pronounce (it was a lager, and it was very different, and he really liked it).

I ordered the Three Sworn Enemies, which was AMAZING. It smelled like fresh oranges and vanilla, tasted like excellent bourbon, and had gold shimmer in it. The glassware is gorgeous, if you're into that sort of thing. It wasn't too loud, it was a great temperature, and I actually wanted to stay and linger, which is not something I usually care to do that much at bars. I'll definitely be back!
author: Amanda P.

description: The cocktail was pretty good, but the bartender was an asshole and the bathroom looked like somebody had died. Unacceptable!
author: David B.

description:
Awesome place to grab a cocktail. AND that's pretty much all they have here. AMAZING COCKTAILS. And inventive sodas for the non-drinkers. About $10-$13 for a drink, but quite reasonable as they are hefty and strong, but somehow still taste wonderful. Every one of their drinks are beautiful. I forget which one I always get here, but it LEGIT looks like it has a whole mint plant in there, along with some blackcurrants and a pearl on a toothpick, and some powdered sugar on top. I SHIT YOU NOT.

Plenty of seating and dimly lit. More suited for groups of 4 or less. Great place to chat and catch up.

If only they had a kitchen... but, alas, there are plenty of quick places to grab a bite - I like accompanying my alcohol with food though (or rather, food with alcohol - because food always comes first, duh).
author: Emily C.

description: I love this place! It is so unique and I love watching the bar tender make the drinks! Shes like a mad scientist! The only thing is there was only one bar tender and it was packed... but I definitely would go there again!
author: Leticia L.

description:
From what I remember I had a 'Three sworn enemies' and a 'Bourbon Crusta' cocktails to drink. 

Both were noteworthy since they were literally the only things listed on the draft of this review!
author: Andi T.

description:
People loved Jazz At Pearl's, the previous venue that resided in this space, so these were some big shoes to fill.  It's a great thing when someone can takeover a well known space & redo it in such a way that it feels like something else completely.   And it feels good.  The Bourbon & Branch team have done it again.

Of course, w this team comes stellar, unique, artisan cocktails.  But, an entire menu of house made soda & nonalcoholic drinks?  What?!  How refreshing & genius!  

These boys are pioneers.

It's beautiful.  We stopped in after having dinner @ Doc Ricketts.  It was around 9:30.  We easily got spots at the bar, which was especially lucky for Friday night.  

It's all about timing.  

I ordered 2 drinks.  First, I asked for something that is not on the menu.  I wanted a skinny margarita.  The bartender listened to my specifications, & she came through beautifully.  

Next up, I asked for a pisco punch.  Wow.  It's way too easy to drink.  Refreshing, & happily it's not too sweet.  

The majority of the tables are reserved, & it's standing room only at the bar.  No barstools in keeping w the old Barbary Coast days, when there was never seating at the bar.  You only stood at the bar, & you sat at a table.  

A great addition to North Beach.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Stop one on an impromptu bar hopping night. On Friday, May 8th around 6pm, we walked in with a party of three. We didn't have a reservation, but it was only half filled, so we easily got a table.

*Devil's manhattan ($10): rye, sweet vermouth, boker's and orange bitters, champagne
*Lauchlan's antiscorbutic ($10): old tom gin, navy strength gin, lime cordial, lime juice, sea salt
*Ammonia coke ($6): with Mexican coca cola, aromatic spirits of ammonia
*Prescription julep ($10): cognac, rye, mint, gomme, pebble ice
*Three sworn enemies ($10): cyrus noble bourbon, grand poppy, vanilla syrup, angostura and orange bitters, gold dust
*Aberlour 18 year ($18): speyside

I ordered the Devil's manhattan and the Aberlour. After my first sip of the manhattan, I actually wasn't sure if I liked it. It was almost too sweet for me. But as I gave it some time, the flavors blended and mellowed out and I enjoyed the drink. After that I just wanted something neat, so I ordered the aberlour.

Service was great! It is a little on the slower side, but I didn't mind. We were here to catch up and enjoy our drinks. But if you're in a hurry and just want a quick drink, this may not be place for you. You'll want to sit back and enjoy your company while they craft you a great cocktail!
author: Elena N.

description:
Came here for a birthday party that met on the bottom floor, in a cute little alcove.
Hiawatha soda tasted very syrupy, but had a nice presentation in a tall cylindrical glass, accented on top with a toothpick that had a pearl in it.
Ginger beer was very gingery, so great if you like that, but I prefer mine to be a bit sweeter and less sharp.
Being a large and newer establishment, The Devil's Acre was clean, not too loud, and spacious.  The bar had a great selection of non-alcoholic beverages, and the menu is very easy to read and well thought out.  Lots of seating as well.
author: Christina G.

description:
********************* 1518 **********************

We came here for a special event recently. They catered the food in, the tacos was so good. All the cocktails were on point. The bartenders were gracious, charming, and shake it up the bar to another level.

Music was good. Everyone got their grooving on. I just wish the line to the bathroom downstair was shorter and the place wasn't overly packed like sardines in the can. And of course a few chic got their drinks on my dress, other than that, we enjoyed our time here!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
There is obviously no shortage of hand-crafted cocktails in San Francisco.  Personally, I enjoy the creative cocktail competition that has evolved, and The Devil's Acre has arrived to the competition prepared and ready! What a welcome addition to the list of fun destinations in North Beach. 

The menu is a crafty throwback to the Barbary Coast speakeasy years.  There are pages and pages of drink options.  Of course, you can always allow the bartender to surprise you.  They don't serve food, so be prepared to grab a slice of Tony's or eat a big dinner beforehad

Bonus tip:  plan ahead and reserve a table on the Devil's Acre website
author: Andrea H.

description: Super cool place for a drink. Using ingredients not so typical and a bit old fashioned, they are making hip and delicious drinks. There's no table service so you need to order from the bar, which we didn't know being this was the first time in so it was a slight annoyance that the busboy didn't inform us. Would like to try other drink the next time in.
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
Wow this might be my favorite bar in SF. I'm a huge cocktail nut (heh) and can definitely appreciate a well crafted drink in a nice lounge environment. They have a huge selection of spirits and the specialty drinks that I tried are all delicious. I had the Bourbon Crusta, Clover Leaf, Sherry Cobbler, and Pisco Punch. The sugar coated rum of the Bourbon Crusta was a great touch, but my favorite drink had to be the Sherry Cobbler. They have a bushel of mint sticking out of the drink so you can bury your nose into the mint while you take a sip out it - great touch!

They have a really cool Barbary Coast theme. I can't get enough of their menu! Of course it has all the listings for drinks, but it's designed like an old-fashioned brochure and also includes cool extras like astrological signs and advertisements for other local businesses (in old-timey style).
author: Richie Z.

description:
Like a lot of dude bartenders the guy working the night I went in acted like a disinterested douche until the girls show up and suddenly he was chatty as fuck and became the super host.  Clearly he was using his dick to make the drinks. 
The beverages were fine and the bartender was open to making special requests but he was off putting. 
Maybe it was me
author: Tommy W.

description:
We love it here. Part of the fun is Ruben at the door--what a sweetheart...and tough when he needs to be I'm sure : )
The vibe is chill, talented bartenders and they make delicious cocktails. The decor is cool and we definitely wish we could hang out more often.
author: Shelley C.

description: What a fabulous random find! Coming to The Devil's Acre before dinner at Cotogna was a great way to wind down from the work day. In coming here on a Tuesday night, reservations weren't entirely necessary, but like anything that's good in SF, it gets busy and having a reservation could be clutch.  Unlike most bars, there's no walking up to the bar to order a drink.  The table service is much appreciated and welcomed after perusing through their fantastic cocktail menu.  For people not interested in imbibing in alcohol, there are hand-craft soda cocktail options! In having their Angostura Phosphate, I could drink that all day and not miss the alcohol buzz. Stop in if you're on your way to dinner, to stay awhile and hang out in their great living room esque sitting area!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Cocktails were solid, but the overall experience here was just okay due to extremely slow service.

Came here on a Saturday night and it was clear that the bartenders were way understaffed, with ~4 of them trying to serve the entire venue of ~100 people. It took us forever to get our drinks, with zero to little acknowledgement from the bartenders that they would get to us soon.  Instead, one of the bartenders decided to take a group of girls' orders before us when we had been already waiting for at least 15 minutes (they just got there) while the other female bartender in front of us looked super annoyed to be there...
author: Claudia C.

description: I have one main policy in life:  never honor anyone or anything which honors the devil.
author: Kyle K.

description:
At the mature age of 30 I never thought I'd find myself in North Beach on a Saturday night. I mean, isn't that like so five years ago? At least for me it was. These days I'm more likely to be shaking my own cocktails at home and entertaining than going out on the town. Or I may be covered in cat fur searching for something decent to watch on Netflix. Who knows? 

North Beach on a Saturday or any day of the week is now vastly improved with the newly opened Devil's Acre, the newest and shiniest watering hole from the Future Bars crew. Like everything they do, this place is a real stunner. Gorgeous and imposing carved bar, amazing sconces and chandeliers, and grand windows facing Columbus. Like all of their bars, the light is low and the attention to detail is fine.

You can peruse the many pages of the Devil's Acre 'almanac' to pick your poison. The Barbary Coast Originals section and the Period Specific Classics were my go to categories, but there are some period appropriate non-alcoholic tonics at the back of the menu including an Ammonia Coke with aromatic spirits of ammonia. Say what? So much to learn. The Golden Era, a perfectly perky refreshment of gin, applejack and dry vermouth with orchard syrup (don't know what it is but I like it) was my favorite of the evening, but my sweetie's Paramour, a gin, Campari and chartreuse offering was a treat too. Our friend even had gold dust in her cocktail called Three Sworn Enemies, a bitter bourbon drink apparently fortified by little flecks of gold. 

While all of these elements would lend themselves well to an intimate speakeasy, the Devil's Acre was oppressively loud. Granted it was a Saturday and it is North Beach, and password protecting your bar is like so three years ago, but I was expecting something a bit more low key and less noisy. We came to catch up with friends but ended up having to do most of it later after leaving. But, reserved seats through Seat Me allowed us to have our own table of four at a prime time, and for that I was grateful. Our servers were a bit overwhelmed with the chaos but they had smiles on their faces and were very congenial.

All cocktail connoisseurs and queens must stop by, preferably not on a weekend night.
author: Joanna M.

description:
This establishment struggles with liability around their levels of broken glass. Or at least that's the reason I was given last night for not being able to go in wearing a pair of Vibrams. See, they don't allow flip-flops because of the risk of broken glass and the door man decided my shoes were too much like flip flops despite being closed-toe and closed on the sides and back. I asked and was told they wouldn't​ let a woman wearing ballet flats in either (despite that being a trendy and common shoe). I asked if I could talk to a manager, the door man replied he is the manager. When my group of friends arrived, we went down the street to Comstock Saloon where we had tasty drinks (far too many!) and food and were treated with humor and grace.

I don't know what the door man's deal was, but the shoe thing was ridiculous. More likely he just didn't like the look of me. Perhaps I hadn't dressed feminine enough? It's a reminder of what being on the receiving end of discrimination feels like, though also a reminder that I have the luxury of avoiding it by changing my appearance if I want to. I hope others aren't getting the same treatment for things they can't as easily change.
author: Andrea F.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday & it's very quaint with low lighting making it feel very cozy. The bartenders are great and when he noticed we had been waiting very long at the bar after we ordered our drink, he actually gave it to us free of charge! I loved the Sherry Cobbler, my absolute favorite of the night.
author: Anna C.

description: This is an interesting new bar in San Francisco that is styled like an old apothecary bar. The drinks are very good. I didn't find the atmosphere very comfortable. It was a bit too small and spaced out strangely. I like that I could get reservations and actually get seated quickly. There is a cocktail that features gold dust, which is just way cool. Of the several other cocktails I tasted, they were all excellent.
author: Ryan L.

description:
The Devil's Acre is another excellent creation from the Future Bars team; this particular one goes with a Barbery Coast theme. The venue has a very large upstairs with a bar and plenty of reserved table seating. Unlike Bourbon & Branch, it's fairly easy to get weekend table reservations for various group sizes even for the same day. (There is also a downstairs bar area, but I have yet to try that one out yet.)

The attention to detail in all the aspects of the bar is so remarkable! The (lengthy) drink menu is designed as a period-specific almanac and even has period-specific advertisements in it. The drinks are served with cloth napkins. The skewers used for drinks with fruit toppings have pearls on them. Oh, and the table lanterns are fully functional with a knob to adjust the flame height. I think we had a little too much fun with the lanterns on our first visit and earned a warning from our server...oops!

The drinks themselves are quite amazing. I'm still working my way through the menu, but some of my favorites are the Bourbon Crusta, Call a Treuse and Three Sworn Enemies. You must try Three Sworn Enemies, which is made with gold dust, for an additional visual treat!

One tip: as the wait for drinks can take a while, plan ahead and order your next drink before you're done with your current one. That said, the wait has never been excessive on any of my trips here and the quality of the drinks makes it well worth the extra time.

Simply put, this is one of my favorite places in the Bay Area to grab a drink with friends.
author: Rodney G.

description:
Great little bar with delicious drinks!
Came here on Thursday to a relatively busy bar. The bar area was crowded, but the seating area was empty. Grabbed our drinks at the bar, got a table, and sat to enjoy the live music.

I loved the Bourbon Cruta - perfect bourbon drink that's a little sweet! My cup of tea (or bourbon).
My friend got the Three Sworn Enemies, another bourbon drink that came w/ gold dust in it. Literally - looks like gold glitter was sprinkled throughout the drink. Was very pretty to look at, but the drink was a little strong for my liking!

Will be back!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Devil's Acre churns out a pretty mean cocktail. A small group of us stumbled in a few weekends ago in search of relief from the chilly winds and a solid cocktail, and found

THE LOW-DOWN.
+ Hand-crafted quality cocktails (I recommend the Clove Leaf!)
+ Friendly, knowledgeable bartenders
+ Very swanky-swank atmosphere (perfect for dates or small groups)
+ A possible speakeasy downstairs? 

Wait-time for drinks can vary, especially when the bartenders are swamped, but patience will get you there, they're all pretty nice people. I would definitely drop by for a drink if I was back in the area!
author: Claire S.

description: We were walking down to Barbarossa when we ran across this little gem. We got there around 8:15pm and didn't have to wait for a table which was nice. I had a deliciou Pisco Punch that tasted nothing like a pisco sour. The menue is short but it looks to be a fully stocked bar so I'm almost certain you could just ask for whatever you like or ask the bar tender to cook something up based on your palette.
author: Jaedra D.

description:
The Devil's Acre is a truly classy place with a long menu of drinks that can be rather dizzying. Luckily the service is amazing! Our hostess made excellent recommendations based off the flavors we were craving. Cocktails ranged from $11-$13. The medicinal and old-timey theme greatly added to this unique bar. 

Make sure to keep your eye out for a "secret" bar... ;)
author: Naveena S.

description: We stopped in for a drink and got way more than expected. The bartender Carson was one of the BEST bartenders we have ever come across and we're from Las Vegas. He taught us a couple things and made some pretty awesome cocktails. I would recommend this place to any and everyone. Very chill, cool spot.
author: Tawny L.

description: I have been here several times on different occasions. Most the time I have had a decent time, excluding the time I ordered a whiskey drink and found a fly at the bottom of my ice cube. The most recent time I was very excited because I was able to make reservations via yelp on New Years Eve around 8pm! That day I confirmed my reservation with yelp through text. My girlfriend and I got some drinks down the street at Comstock and by the time my reservation was ready we walked up the street. We got to Devil's Acre and there was no one there except one bartender cleaning glasses and the doors were locked! I called their phone several times and no one answered but I did leave a message expressing my preicament and left my name and phone number. I understand being closed for a private party for New Years Eve but the fact that I was able to make a reservation, confirm said reservation, and no one answered the phone to make amends is ridiculous and insulting! I called a few days later to get some answers and still no one answered. I will not be coming after this experience also considering Comstock Saloon and 15 Romolo are closeby.
author: Alex N.

description: Great bar and atmosphere, but the menu is awful.  Every person who walks into bar either knows what they want or wants few house cocktail options.  Throwing a book at me when I sit down at the bar is a non starter.
author: Curt R.

description: Great drinks!! Went on a Sunday evening and it was the perfect time to stop in and have a drink. Very impressed with the bartender/mixologist. We will for sure stop in again.
author: Allen O.

description:
TL;DR: Apothecary bar. Strong drinks. Gold flakes?!

After reading articles about this "secret" bar, we thought we'd try this place out. When you walk in, you make a right and walk through all the tables and you'll see a set of poorly lit stairs. Take them down and you'll reach an apothecary style bar. 

The drinks are very strong and very tasty. I got the St. Croix Fix, which was a rum based pineapple drink. My friend ordered the Three Sworn Enemies, a bourbon based drink with poppy liquor and gold flakes. We called it the hipster viniq. It was shimmery and very very strong. 

I don't think think place has an happy hour but the prices really aren't that bad. You're looking to pay $9-11 for their specialty cocktails. You'll really only need 1 or 2 to get to a good level of intoxication.
author: Steven L.

description:
mixed drinks were good
nothing crazy
drinks were 11 a piece
environment was quite but we were there before 8
mixed drink was good
but I personally like more options
it was dimm lighting
author: Tabitha D.

description: Good drinks in a cute venue. But I did my birthday party here and was disappointed with the event coordinator. She wasn't thorough and there were several details that she overlooked and I ended up stressed on my birthday. I'll return here for drinks but probably wouldn't book anything big with this group of bars again.
author: Cathy L.

description: Great bar. The atmosphere, the service, so much fun. The "Golden Era" is delicious. We were here on a Tuesday and there was a jazz flute player! Really good.
author: Karen A.

description:
Second bar in our slight adventure in north beach area. This place had a lot more seating than the last place, but there was also many more drinks. I will admit I did like the almanac theme to the drinks menu. The drinks were separated by alcohol which made it easy to find drinks I liked and didn't like. 

The drink I ended up ordering was the vodka cocktail which had a little too strong for me. I like my drinks strong, but I'd still like to be able to drink them. 

The atmosphere is great, very saloon like! Love it. 

Pro tip: get there early and get a great seat.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I guess I don't get it.  According to the description it is supposed to be a speak easy.  However, when you walk up and the doors are wide open and it is loud and rowdy like any bar and you walk straight in, it seems to not have the main characteristics of a speak easy.  We were initially excited to try a new place but this was not a place that we will be going back to.  It is just a place to sit around with a lot of very loud people who are dressed sloppy and have bad service.  There is a room downstairs that is a little more along the lines of a speak easy but it is hot and uncomfortable and doesn't have table service.

If we knew going in what it was going to be I think we would have been a little more interested but this what this is being billed as and what it is are two very different things.  If you want a speak easy experience stick with Bourbon and Branch or Wilson and Wilson.
author: Sheryl C.

description:
I'm a sucker for anything old-fashioned, and The Devil's Acre more than fits the bill. I came here for date night and 36 questions, and neither disappointed. Upon arriving, we were given the option of giving up our table to enjoy the bar below. Next time we come, we'll definitely be checking it out--I've heard they have excellent tastings. I shouldn't have been so surprised, given The Devil's Acre is a sister to Bourbon & Branch, another favorite speakeasy in the city.

The menu was filled with a great selection of cocktails and non-alcoholic drinks. Drinks were unique, delicious, not too sweet, and not too expensive. We started the night with Bourbon Crustas, moved on to the Sherry Cobbler, and spent the rest of the evening trying cocktails on the wait staff's suggestions. The sugar rimming the Bourbon Crusta was delicious--I think it was my favorite of the evening.

I particularly enjoyed the feeling of being transported back in time. Pair this with it's location across the street from City Lights, and there is no better way to spend an evening.

Advice: definitely get a reservation, this place fills up quick.
author: Nicole C.

description: Really nice atmosphere. Love the dragons and details. My husband and I tend to bring folks here when in from out of town. We've had mixed levels of service but for the most part, quite amicable. It's fun to go through the list and try things we haven't before. Most folks go for the Three Sworn Enemies off the bat.
author: Hannah W.

description:
3.5 stars.  Another solid cocktail bar by the B&B team, though I personally like most of the other bars better.

I had the Three Sworn Enemies, with bourbon, Grand Poppy, vanilla, angostura, and gold dust.  I was stunned when the drink came out - it was liquid shimmery gold, and literally looked like a teeny bopper Bath & Body Works product.  When I finally mustered the courage to take a sip, I couldn't pinpoint any flavors in particular so I'm guessing the Grand Poppy was the dominant flavor.  It was definitely interesting, and visually unlike any drink I've ever had, so I'm glad I got it.  That said, I've had more spectacular drinks at B&B, Tradition, W&W...  

I do want to mention the "remedies" that you can add to either your cocktail, soda, or water for $2. My friend added the digestive remedy to the devils manhattan so they stirred up the manhattan, then added a few drops of the remedy tableside.  I wish we had been able to try the drink with and without the remedy, though I'm sure it elevated the drink.  I was initially hesitant about champagne in a manhattan but it was just a splash - just enough to impart a grape-y brightness without being classified as bubbly.  Overall I enjoyed my friend's drink better than mine.  My only worry with the remedies though, is that while the concept is cool, it relies on the customer to know what flavors pair well together and also runs the risk of making an overly complex drink muddled in flavor.

The drinks are $11-12, but then they tack on tax and healthy SF which is kind of annoying.  But there is a highly entertaining astrology part of the menu that made up for it.  I imagine the astrology section would be a great icebreaker for a date.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Super intimidate (if you come after Happy Hour) with yummy drinks. If you're lucky, you may catch a band there which adds to the ambience. I like how the menu is designed. If you're here on a first or second date, it gives you something to talk about.
author: Pawanpreet G.

description: I hve gone to Devil's Acre quite a few times as North Beach is fun place to be. I am their big fan of Devil's Manhattan. I have had the original Manhattans at many authentic places and I have learned to make one the right way. However, I still like the Devil's way. Place is very cool and food places are right around it. The bartenders are very courteous and they serve with a big smile. They are willing to give you their recommendations of food places and they seem to love their jobs. We usualy sit at the bar and watch them make the drinks, it's a thrill!!
author: Rex T.

description:
Stopped by after dinner for a cocktail.  Really loud speak easy styled venue with really powerfully packed cocktails.  

I guess we just aren't specialty cocktail folks as they were too flavorfully concocted for our tastes.

Give us straightforward gin and tonics, martini's, margaritas any day.  They are inventive drinks however and give a strong impression from the get go.

Stop by if you want to try something new.
author: Susan C.

description:
Take one part impeccable service. Add two parts glorious cocktails. Stir in an apothecary theme. Dash in a real-life herbalist to create the menu. Serve neat and garnish with live jazz until last call. 

From the geniuses that brought you Bourbon & Branch, The Devil's Acre is a recipe for success, completely unique and a no-brainer 5-star bar. Found this place on Yelp and marked it as a must-go during my recent trip to the Bay area. My friends and I arrived for our 9pm reservation on a Thursday. The decor and aesthetics are completely original. They've got everything from vintage scientist eye droppers to more than 100 century-old chemists canisters. And if you want the legit speakeasy experience, head down to basement bar hidden down an unmarked staircase in the back.

Thirsty? Hell yes we were. In fitting with the apothecary theme, all cocktails are presented as "remedies" on the menu. Very fun and inventive. Collectively, the five of us ordered about 15 drinks total (it's a miracle we didn't black out). But anyway, those definitely worthy of a mention were the The Golden Age, Pisco Punch, Bourbon Crusta, and Three Sworn Enemies. All were well-executed and well-balanced. I was particularly taken with the Three Sworn Enemies, not only because I'm a complete sucker for old fashions, but there's actual edible gold dust in the drink. Gold, son!! Complete novetly, I know, but c'mon who doesn't love shiny things? 

To cap off the evening, I went off menu asked for a spicy gin-based cocktail. SO GLAD I DID. The waitress came back with a concoction of gin, ghost pepper tincture, lime juice, and raspberry puree. Wow...the drink was beyond bonkers. Fruity/spicy/boozy ambrosia. The mixologists are truly masters of their craft. 

Seriously, forget bar-hopping. Devil's Acre is a "last stop" (or "only stop") kind of place, and not for just -A- drink. You'll be back for another round. I know I will.
author: Joel P.

description: Lovely place, wonderful atmosphere and good drinks.  We would definitely come here again to try their different drinks. I had the ginger beef which was made from scratch since I was DD. Everyone else really enjoyed their drinks.
author: Anh T.

description:
Stopped in for drinks with an old friend before she moved away. 

Notes:
Great ambiance and plenty of seating. 
Craft drinks are good with variety.
When it gets busy, theres only two bartenders and we're forced to only order drinks at the bar.
Not really a place to sit down and chat with the live jazz band jamming. 

Would definitely come back here just be cognizant of the notes and you may have two drinks tops in a couple hours visiting with a date or company.
author: Rafael R.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars in San Francisco. It is a sister restaurant of Bourbon and Branch (speakeasy bar in the city). I love the ambiance its crowded but not too crowded. Upstairs the restaurant has a pretty open bar seating (dim lighting) and great service. The cocktails on the menu are broken up by the type of alcohol and they also have non-spirits.

Downstairs its a very interesting style setup with an olden day mailboxes, small hallways, and a separate bar. Most of the flights and tastings happened downstairs--they sometimes run tastings open for the public for first come first serve.

Great place, crowd and service! I would highly recommend. Great addition to North beach and adds an interesting speakeasy culture mixed in with all the other Italian places in North beach.
author: Kunal T.

description: Really enjoyed this spacious speakeasy spot on a Friday night after dinner at nearby Trestle. Without live music it was pretty quiet and we had an easy time getting a table. Our waitress was very helpful with the cocktail options -- recommend the Three Sworn Enemies (which also had "gold dust" for the kicker). From the Local Edition / Bourbon & Branch folks, I'd rate this above Local Edition but below B&B.
author: Shirley L.

description:
Big fan of this place. Strong, tasty, inventive cocktails and love the apothecary theme. We came around 4pm, and it was empty - we snagged a table upstairs without any issues.  Perfect setting for a day date or to catch up with friends. 

Service was extremely attentive. 

Wish they sold food - I get hungry when I'm three cocktails deep!

I personally enjoyed the St. Croix something - it was a rum cocktail and tasted pineapply.  So refreshing!
author: Ashlee C.

description:
Oh yes please... you hidden little gem you.

Went here for the Hitchcock hour provided by SOSH and it was freaking great!  The decor/ambiance was perfect.  The drinks were fantastic, the service was divine, and the fact that it was in a hidden section under the bar made it all the more interesting.

I would definitely come here again, whether it be a special event or I was just in the neighbor hood with some friends.
author: Sara N.

description:
The rudest service ever. This is late on a Saturday night where there were some open tables and a small crowd at the bar. Just the highlights. 

-bro waiter with bro stash visibly annoyed that more people showed up at our table than we planned. Threatened to disband our table and send us to the bar if any more people showed up.  Sorry for giving you more money for your goods and services. 

-ran the group drink ordering process like a confused JV drill sergeant. In an attempt to make to process more orderly he just made it more hostile. I'm sure he was trying to be funny, but once that fell flat he decided it was best to try that approach again. Fail. 


Tasty drinks though.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Bar: great vibe, great selection and great menu. There are some liquors here that I've never even heard of!

Service: Our bartender was super knowledgeable on everything behind her bar (down to the ice.) However, I wish she was just a little more friendly!

Will definitely be back!
author: Brittani T.

description: Stopped for a quick drink hoping to get into the speakeasy but only to find out it's only open on the weekend. Had a good chat with a bartender by the name of Carson. He was great, super chill and personable. Just what a bartender should be. I def recommend.
author: Erica J.

description: The Golden Era tastes like Apple Jacks. Delicious. Atmosphere was nice on a Friday night, not too crowded but had a stream of people.
author: Anthony T.

description: Showed up at our reservation time and ended up waiting for quite a while. They were busy however when you make reservations to a bar / lounge and are on time you should feel welcomed and brought to your table in a acceptable amount of time. This wasn't the case. We waited about 20 minutes and felt like it didn't matter that we stayed or left. The space is nice. Definitely a throw back in time. Music was mostly 80's which was kind of cool. The thing that wasn't good was the service. After we were seated it took another 20 minutes to take our drink order. So we are now 40 minutes in and we are all starting to feel annoyed. There was literally one or two servers serving an entire seated reservation area. Not great on a Sat. night. The drinks took another 25 minutes and were average at best. The place is supposed to be about mixology and flavorful cocktails. We all didn't find this to be the case. There are definitely better places in the SF for craft cocktails.
author: DARREN M.

description: Beautiful apothecary style cocktails. Intimate bar area mixed with petite cocktail tables and comfy lounge furniture. The lighting is dim, the music is chill, the service is friendly, and the crowd is mellow and keeps to itself. Its a delicate ecosystem at which we can all marvel.
author: Elle B.

description: This place was amazing! Stumbled onto it by accident after a great Italian meal in North Beach, but boy were we happy we did. Incredible cocktails, a very cool, bohemian theme and extremely friendly and attentive staff. Highly recommend a visit here!
author: Ashley G.

description: Beautiful atmosphere, helpful bar staff and seating available in bar area. You can also make reservations to sit at a table and have cocktail waitress take care of you. I asked for a basil gimlet, they don't have basil but the bartender made a recommendation that was great! I will for sure be back!
author: Sarah S.

description:
This place deserves 6 stars!

This place is a sister bar of Burbon and Branch, but the prices are a lot less.  Love that!  The biggest difference between this bar and other speakeasies is that this bar is set during the Barbary Coast era.  While, speakeasies were during the 1920's-early 1930's, the Barbary coast was from 1860's-early 1900's.  

They have 2 seating areas:  The main one on the ground level, and a smaller one downstairs.  You will need reservations for the ground level seating area, but the downstairs is open seating.  There is also a bar on both floors.  

I started with the burbon crusta, which had burbon, lemon, orchard syrup, orange curacao, maraschino, and banker's bitters.  This was quite a refreshing and delicious drink.  The cost was $10.  Side note: The recipe for this cocktail also came on all the coasters.  I also shared the sherry cobbler (sherry, lemon-lime syrup, pebble ice, fruit and mint), again another $10 drink.  This one took a few sips to get use to (could be because burbon was the last thing on my palate), but then it became really really good!

The service was great.  Quick to your table, and had some great suggestions.  She even helped to spruce up my burbon crusta cocktail halfway through by adding some Love Potion to it, to help change the flavor of it.  

When we went the soda machine was still being installed, so couldn't try some of their elixirs/sodas.  But I do want to go back and try them.  You can use them to create your own cocktail.  Choose an elixir and then a liquor.  Love the idea.  

I can't wait to go back again soon!
author: Rose Z.

description:
Unfortunately I didn't have as great an experience as so many other people did. Maybe it was a fluke for the evening, but after my part of 4 arrived for reservations and started checking out the drink selection, we were told we would have to leave for a larger party an hour into our reservation. Apparently it's stated when you make reservations that they are for 2 - 2.5 hours which could have been my mistake for not doing thorough research...but didn't change they fact that we were being told an hour into our reservation. 

After some discussion we were able to be moved to another table to continue to get our drink on. We didn't mind the move, but if they needed the seating it would have been nice to be asked instead of told to leave. 

Now the drinks is where I was most disappointed.
